bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean from Philip Showalter Hench, March 14, 1941

div1.p: Kean disagrees with Hench's proposal for the yellow fever painting. He also describes Finlay as an honest man but lacking a truly scientific mind.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean from Philip Showalter Hench, March 14, 1941
div1.p:
I have been a very poor correspondent
lately. I have not been well, and the income tax
has been a burden for so poor a man. Mrs. K. has
besides this house a couple of little ones which the
rents and so Rents & Royalties with its schedules of depre-
ciation, repairs, mortgates, &c. has been a headache.
But that is now over, tho. there is another for the city
due at the end of the month. I have just waked
up to the fact that you will start in your journey
a week from Today so I will get this off by
air mail today to wish you Bon Voyage. Your
last letter was rec'd on the 7th and you had not re-
ceived my of course my letter mailed on the 6th
inclosing my letter to his Exc. Dr. Domingo Ramos
and the copy of your memo. for him which is so
complete and convincing as to remove any
possibility of doubt on the question at issue.
The Copy of the True Comies came yesterday and
was interesting and very amusing. To see
Lazear without his black beard & dead old Dr.
Finlay, who was 67 in 1900, looking like a young
Cavalry man & without his side whiskers (Burnsides)
which he always wore, pointing at that large
mosquito (which is by the way an anopheles, standing on

her head to bite, and not a stegomyia) But the essen-
tial points are near enough to the truth to be very
educational. As regards Mr. Kellogg and Mr. Corn-
well and the proposed picture I am of an uncer-
tain mind. As a picture I cannot see Walter
Reed arranged with his assistants, as if for a photo-
graph, with Lazear putting the mosquito on Carroll.
The historical verities are too much opposed to
such a picture. I cannot but feel that Cornwell has
the best group if he will only have Lazear (who was the
mosquito expert) by Reed's side, both of them full
face, while Dr. Finlay might be in profile and Dr.
Delgado omitted. I wonder if Carroll & Agramonte
were really with Reed on that occasion? It doesn't
matter though, they would have to be in the picture
anyhow. As an artistic group I see always in
my mind's eye Reed talking to General Wood
in the embrasure of the palace window on Oct. 12
and telling him that the mystery of the ages has been
solved. But of course we cannot leave out Finlay
and Lazear and we cannot put them into
that picture. I ran across a letter which I
wrote 14 years ago to Dr. Gorge Le Roy the Editor of
Le Boletin Oficial de Sauidad on the Finlay-Reed
controversy, and I am surprised to see how
accurately it expresses my feeling Today.

I am now not quite as positive that he may not
some how have a case of yellow fever among his
104 experiments, the Jesuit Padre Urra, or another,
as I was there and I have been intending to take
a day or two off and study Dr. Finlay's very
careful and honest records. He was an absolutely
honest man in every way, but was given to
wishful thinking and lacked the wary scepticism
of the truly scientific mind. I could tell you of some
amusing instances if I could see you & have a chat.
His claim that the bites of unripe infected stegomyia
would cause immunity, or a very wild immunizing
fever, is I think disproved by several of the cases
of which he had cognizance-Moran for instance
who was bitten twice in Nov. but was not immune on Dec 21
when he went into Building No. 2. Of course too he had
to stretch his period of incubation to excessive length
(25 days) to bring in some of them. But he was an
excellent clinician and his diagnoses was usually
accepted by the other members of the yellow fever Board
while they yet rejected his mosquito theory.
I am sorry that you have not been able to carry
out your original plan of going via San Francisco.

closer.salute: With all good wishes, Sincerely your friend
